Ratings.comment: Good instructor.  Kind.  Pleasant.  Knows her stuff.  Interesting guest speakers.
Very good quality.  Very good instructor.  Very helpful to students.  Wonderful.  Professionally knowledgeable.

Excellent.  Previously Boeing 747 flight instructor.   Super industrious female with engineering background.  A stickler for detail.  Very sincere.  Wants everyone to succeed.  On her way to a PhD.  Invited class speakers from airports, including control tower staff and facilities planners who add new terminals.  Full class.  Exciting topics.

Very sincere, interesting, and amusing teacher.  If you're fortunate enough to get her for the class, be thankful.  Exams are, based on the FAA, multichoice and should be prepped for using nothing but the FAA Test Prep.  Homework, however, is graded quite harshly.  Give thorough answers.  Still easy but care needs to be put in here to hold an A
Litvay manages to take the dry topic of airline network analysis and hold interesting, attention grabbing discussions.  She is awesome!

She's very hyped up on caffeine, but the class is very easy, and interesting, at least to me.  No need to buy a book for this class, save a 12 novel widely available.  Highly recommended, but then again you have to take this class to be in the aviation program anyways...
Easy and love this class but unfortunately i missed an A, because i forgot to summit a big part of a 15% grade homework... she won't let me turn in late, kinda creapy
keeps class interesting, extemely easy.
Interesting and Easy class..nice professor
Good
Hyper, very interested in what she is teaching
Good teacher for AV300, watch out in 310.  It gets alot harder.  A lot of material to cover and the class moves fast.
She knows what she is talking about, and let's face it- women who can fly Boeing 737s are cool.
really nice and clear.  Very helpfull
Robyn is an awesome instructor.  Very laid back and fun.  She seems to really enjoy teaching.
Very Hyper...but fun to have as a teacher..not to hard..but a fun class

Great Professor and did his best to make sure everyone understood. Class is easy as long as you make a solid attempt although there are very few graded assignments overall so doing good on them is a must.

Matt is a good instructor. He is a little soft-spoken, but he always makes sure that you can hear. The grading for his class is black and white. USE THE ASA TEST PREP BOOK. It's like $12 and the questions on every assignment are taken directly from that book. The class is easy if you just listen to what he teaches.
Matt is one of the best lecturers I have. He takes time to address every question and gives his own stories while lecturing. He knows his stuff and I am excited to have him again.

This wasn't a traditional class. This was for the aviation spring break study abroad trip. Professor Dreher did a great job preparing us for our trip to France & Spain. Before we left, we learned about aviation history in the two countries. When were there he did a great job making sure that everything went well. Overall, it was a fun experience.

Super good lecturer for a pretty easy class that really cares about educating his students. His slideshows are interesting, he has his own stories that apply to the curriculum, and is just very laid back in general. He also offers corrections for up to 50% of the points back on homework/quizzes/midterms.

I've had Matt for three classes at this point, and he's a good professor that cares about his students. It's not difficult to get an A in his classes as long as you do the work - there's always some sort of extra credit.
Very laid back class that is focused on learning over assignments.
Has a deep knowledge of aviation with many interesting and informative stories to share. A great person who really cares and wants you to succeed.

Professor Dreher is one of the best professors that I have had. Class is very simple. Usually just a lecture and then a quick in class assignment. He made sure to make class interesting. For example, we got to see drones fly instead of having a lecture. For reading quizzes and test, just make sure to review the material and actually look at it.
Great teacher, tells good stories. I always enjoyed his class

Matt was amazing and he really wants his students to do well. He provides good feedback and genuinely enjoys what he's teaching. The class is pretty easy if you do all the outside readings which are actually pretty interesting and I would absolutely take his class again

Professor Dreher is awesome. Lectures are helpful and informational. I recommend getting the ASA text book, all of the quizzes and exams use questions from it. He also has stories that relate to the subject matter that keeps the class fun and interesting.
This was a study abroad class and so much fun! I was able to take this as an aviation elective. He is such a great guy, cares about his students, and wants everyone to do well.
Such a good proffeser really kind and is willing to work with students! Is really passionate about avaition and makes the classs so fun!!!!!!!
AVIATN 2000 is easy and a light workload for a 3 credit hour class. I recommend it.

Matt Dreher is a great lecturer. The slides he provides are adequate enough to get an A. Allows students to rework questions to improve test scores. Extra credit is always available. 

The material is hard but Matt Dreher made it understandable.
Very caring professor, one of the only ones that work hard to make sure you understand the material

Dreher is a good lecturer, I actually took 2300 with him but this wasn't an option. Easy to navigate class, and straightforward lectures and assignments. However, very very difficult to get into contact with through email and it was an asynchronous class so that left a few of us high and dry for exams. Textbook heavy, HW or quiz every week or two.

You can tell that he is passionate about Aviation and he tries to make the classes interesting. I thought this course was pretty easy and it was taken online with no set meeting times. I enjoyed it though and learned a lot.

Matt was incredible! I cannot recommend him enough! I genuinely enjoyed watching all of his lectures; he's so knowledgeable but was able to break down tough concepts! He clearly cared about his students and always went out of his way to be accomodating! I 100% recommend taking this class even if you aren't an aviation major (I'm not!).
Good instructor.  Kind.  Pleasant.  Knows her stuff.  Interesting guest speakers.
Very good quality.  Very good instructor.  Very helpful to students.  Wonderful.  Professionally knowledgeable.

Excellent.  Previously Boeing 747 flight instructor.   Super industrious female with engineering background.  A stickler for detail.  Very sincere.  Wants everyone to succeed.  On her way to a PhD.  Invited class speakers from airports, including control tower staff and facilities planners who add new terminals.  Full class.  Exciting topics.

Very sincere, interesting, and amusing teacher.  If you're fortunate enough to get her for the class, be thankful.  Exams are, based on the FAA, multichoice and should be prepped for using nothing but the FAA Test Prep.  Homework, however, is graded quite harshly.  Give thorough answers.  Still easy but care needs to be put in here to hold an A
Litvay manages to take the dry topic of airline network analysis and hold interesting, attention grabbing discussions.  She is awesome!

She's very hyped up on caffeine, but the class is very easy, and interesting, at least to me.  No need to buy a book for this class, save a 12 novel widely available.  Highly recommended, but then again you have to take this class to be in the aviation program anyways...
Easy and love this class but unfortunately i missed an A, because i forgot to summit a big part of a 15% grade homework... she won't let me turn in late, kinda creapy
keeps class interesting, extemely easy.
Interesting and Easy class..nice professor
Good
Hyper, very interested in what she is teaching
Good teacher for AV300, watch out in 310.  It gets alot harder.  A lot of material to cover and the class moves fast.
She knows what she is talking about, and let's face it- women who can fly Boeing 737s are cool.
really nice and clear.  Very helpfull
Robyn is an awesome instructor.  Very laid back and fun.  She seems to really enjoy teaching.
Very Hyper...but fun to have as a teacher..not to hard..but a fun class

Professor Serrano was one of the best professors I've had since I started college. The homeworks, quizzes, and exams are very easy and literally copy paste from the ASA private pilot book. You have to try and fail this class, that's how easy it is.

The course is 100% attendance required by the FAA. Alex's teaching style was great and intuitive. Homework and quizzes were all based on the textbook, and if you study the textbook well, you are guaranteed an A.

Professor Serrano made Instrument flight fundamentals very interesting. He encouraged participation in class. He was great at lectures and set up his students for success. This class requires 100% attendance due to the FAA. I had to miss a class due to a meeting. Professor Serrano was flexible, and I was able to make the class up one day.

Alex is one of the best and most caring teachers I have ever had. With this class requiring 100% attendance he will truly do whatever he can to help you make up classes that you miss. He also has very involved lectures where he'll explain every clearly and even talk about his own personal experiences that he's had when he was a pilot.

He is probably my favorite professor at OSU. He truly cares about his students and that they understand the content of the class. He is super approachable and gives you several resources to make sure you succeed in the class. The class is very dependent upon exams as the 2 midterms and final count for 70% of your grade.
Great teacher. Taught the subject well and with great detail. Mixed in stories and videos to lectures to keep class entertaining.
Very lenient, helpful, and understanding
Blawg chill wit the late

Great Professor and did his best to make sure everyone understood. Class is easy as long as you make a solid attempt although there are very few graded assignments overall so doing good on them is a must.

Matt is a good instructor. He is a little soft-spoken, but he always makes sure that you can hear. The grading for his class is black and white. USE THE ASA TEST PREP BOOK. It's like $12 and the questions on every assignment are taken directly from that book. The class is easy if you just listen to what he teaches.
Matt is one of the best lecturers I have. He takes time to address every question and gives his own stories while lecturing. He knows his stuff and I am excited to have him again.

This wasn't a traditional class. This was for the aviation spring break study abroad trip. Professor Dreher did a great job preparing us for our trip to France & Spain. Before we left, we learned about aviation history in the two countries. When were there he did a great job making sure that everything went well. Overall, it was a fun experience.

Super good lecturer for a pretty easy class that really cares about educating his students. His slideshows are interesting, he has his own stories that apply to the curriculum, and is just very laid back in general. He also offers corrections for up to 50% of the points back on homework/quizzes/midterms.

I've had Matt for three classes at this point, and he's a good professor that cares about his students. It's not difficult to get an A in his classes as long as you do the work - there's always some sort of extra credit.
Very laid back class that is focused on learning over assignments.
Has a deep knowledge of aviation with many interesting and informative stories to share. A great person who really cares and wants you to succeed.

Professor Dreher is one of the best professors that I have had. Class is very simple. Usually just a lecture and then a quick in class assignment. He made sure to make class interesting. For example, we got to see drones fly instead of having a lecture. For reading quizzes and test, just make sure to review the material and actually look at it.
Great teacher, tells good stories. I always enjoyed his class

Matt was amazing and he really wants his students to do well. He provides good feedback and genuinely enjoys what he's teaching. The class is pretty easy if you do all the outside readings which are actually pretty interesting and I would absolutely take his class again

Professor Dreher is awesome. Lectures are helpful and informational. I recommend getting the ASA text book, all of the quizzes and exams use questions from it. He also has stories that relate to the subject matter that keeps the class fun and interesting.
This was a study abroad class and so much fun! I was able to take this as an aviation elective. He is such a great guy, cares about his students, and wants everyone to do well.
Such a good proffeser really kind and is willing to work with students! Is really passionate about avaition and makes the classs so fun!!!!!!!
AVIATN 2000 is easy and a light workload for a 3 credit hour class. I recommend it.

Matt Dreher is a great lecturer. The slides he provides are adequate enough to get an A. Allows students to rework questions to improve test scores. Extra credit is always available. 

The material is hard but Matt Dreher made it understandable.
Very caring professor, one of the only ones that work hard to make sure you understand the material

Dreher is a good lecturer, I actually took 2300 with him but this wasn't an option. Easy to navigate class, and straightforward lectures and assignments. However, very very difficult to get into contact with through email and it was an asynchronous class so that left a few of us high and dry for exams. Textbook heavy, HW or quiz every week or two.

You can tell that he is passionate about Aviation and he tries to make the classes interesting. I thought this course was pretty easy and it was taken online with no set meeting times. I enjoyed it though and learned a lot.

Matt was incredible! I cannot recommend him enough! I genuinely enjoyed watching all of his lectures; he's so knowledgeable but was able to break down tough concepts! He clearly cared about his students and always went out of his way to be accomodating! I 100% recommend taking this class even if you aren't an aviation major (I'm not!).

Matt was an amazing, caring, funny, intelligent, and helpful instructor. Unfortunately, this class is FAA accredited and the government makes things hard that don't need to be, however Matt breaks the mandatory PowerPoints down into simple concepts on his own. I had to drop this class due to personal reasons, but I would have received a B+ at least
Matthew is a great professor. His material is well put together and his passion for aviation is obvious. Fun class.

Matt is great! If you want to fly with OSU, just take his ground school class. He gives lots of helpful stuffs and helps you prepare for the FAA test. Exams are just from prep book. He cares his students and answers all the questions!
Very knowledgeable about first-year students and is a good advisor. it sometimes gets annoying listening to her, but her class isn't bad. I might take one of her classes in the future if I have to.
It is an easy class if you are majoring in anything related to aviation—weekly assignments, quizzes, and discussions. Asynchronous as well!

Lots of busy work that felt a little unnecessary at times and she was occasionally lacking in clarity for some assignments, but overall very easy fully online asynchronous course. You should get an A as long as you put a decent amount of effort into completing weekly assignments.

Dr. Emily Castellucci was a wonderful start to my Aviation Management experience at OSU. I enjoyed the self paced lectures and writing assignments that really made students dig deeper and think about an aspect of aviation they are most likely unfamiliar with. This class really encompasses every major part of the aviation industry.
Lectures were clear cut, never needed to use outside resources, class was easy and clear - cut, requires purchase of a documentary for about $15, and requires a museum visit on your own time.

You will have 1-3 hours of recorded lecture materials per week, on top of labs which can take upwards of 8 hours a week. This was my first GIS class and was an overload of information. She grades so hard on labs as well.

This class was a lot of work, the labs take so much time especially if you mess up and have to start over. But Emily is very accessible outside of class and ready to answer questions. Definitely, more work than I thought, but it was super interesting nonetheless.

Dr. Castellucci is by far one of the best and most caring professors I have had. She takes so much time out of her day to help her students. that being said, the labs for this class are absurd. They assume that you are a professional in geographic software, and they take 5-10 hours a week. The exams are also very tedious.

Castellucci truly cares about her students and offers a ton of resources to do well. The labs can be tedious. Four tests with the lowest grade dropped. Test questions sometimes ask about very specific details (memorize the slides!) but overall not too bad, and there's extra credit available.

Straightforward lectures and labs. Sometimes the material is a bit esoteric, but that's what office hours are for. Rarely touched the textbook except before finals. Emily is a bit standoffish until you get to know her, but she's an accessible instructor doing well with difficult (or sometimes dull) material to teach.

Honestly she was a pretty decent lecturer and most of the time it was very interesting to sit through (with few exceptions). The labs were difficult but good grades are attainable if you work at it. The toughest part was the exams which often had confusing questions making it much harder than the actual subject material.

Labs will take several hours each week, most of which time will be spent by you silently screaming at the computer in your mind while you slowly go insane. You will stare at the lab instructions, which will have steps strategically deleted to inflict maximum suffering. You'll then be asked to pursue this miserable business as a career. Madness.

4 years at Ohio State and by far the hardest professor I have had. She makes her exam 10x harder than they should be. Does not judge you on how well you know the topic, every question is designed to trick you. "choose the false statement" 5 options and one is statement is a single word off. She knows her lectures suck so one missed class is 1% off
Mapping labs were awful, and lectures were dry. To be fair, I am not interested in the subject but had to take it for my degree. Best part of this class was being done.

Honestly, the labs are tedious but the topic is tedious. She writes word for word in her instructions what to do, but it does take a lot of time. Her tests are not hard (not a genius & still got As ), she also drops your lowest exam out of 3. Just fill in the sheets she gives you and memorize everything on those. Lastly, dont read the readings.

Get ready to spend 6 hours a week on the labs. They are extremely long and tedious, and there's one every week. Not only is it pointless and hard, her lectures don't even help. Lectures are boring and she takes attendance. Tests are extremely hard.
Read from the slides during every lecture.

An amazing lecturer! She's easy to meet outside of class and if you do it'll work in your favor. Sometimes if a student started off badly on a test, she would give extra extra credit to help you recover on top of the extra credit already offered. Nice, caring, pleasant to talk to, and really understands what she teaches. Highly recommend!

Dr. Castellucci provides an abundance of (optional) resources such as lecture outlines to fill out, extra credit that prepares students for exams, one-on-one office hour appointments, early lab submissions so students can skip lab without penalty, etc. She strives to set students up for success, and she has inspired me to pursue GIS in my career!

It was a fairly boring class but I appreciated that I knew what to expect each week. She's fairly 'by the books' but it was refreshing to have a professor with a clear grading criteria and little surprises. Her in-class handouts for the lectures were immensely helpful and all I needed for studying. Her labs are probably the trickiest thing.

Emily is easily one of the most caring, considerate professors I've had. She wants you to succeed, but also wants you to learn. Lectures are clear cut and simple, and she's always eager to clarify further. You should expect to do your part though, since she meets you more than halfway. Do labs early and go to lecture and it's smooth sailing

Dr. Castellucci is a caring and fair minded lecturer. She is strict about attendance, but her labs are concise and easy to follow. Tests are multiple choice and straightforward. Readings are provided but not necessary. Attend lecture, take notes, do the labs, and you'll get a good grade without much effort.

She is very new at teaching but caring . Her slides are very helpful, trust me compared to other OSU professors. Her tests are very specific so definitely read her slides if you want to do well on exams. I love the fact she gave extra credit which boosted my grade by one letter grade. Don't purchase the book. Everything is covered in the slides.

My biggest complaint about this course was the lab component. Little direction was given and ArcGIS was difficult to teach myself outside of class. However, Emily has said she will be reforming this portion, so you may be in luck. She's a nice woman-- eager to help and provides loads of extra credit. Boring though; good luck staying awake!

As of this writing, she's a brand new hire, straight out of grad school, teaching three of Geography's core classes. I think she was overwhelmed, but it's clear she has a passion for GIS and for teaching pedagogy and I think she'll settle into professorship nicely.

She is knowledgeable in her field, but her lecture is really boring. The exams are quite specific and mostly focusing on definitions. Her exams are very difficult and the average scores are low. She gives extra credit but it is time consuming and tough  grade. Paying more attention on labs.

She tends to read straight from the slides and her classes end up being very boring. Her tests are very specific and extremely difficult.  There is extra credit you can do but that as well is very hard and time consuming. Be willing to put lots of time into this class and lab. Do not take it if you do not have to.

She is passionate about what she teaches, but her classes are so boring. Out who is signed up for the class only about 20% actually show up.  Be willing to spend hours on lab work. The tests she gives are very difficult with a very low grade point average. Overall she is a nice teacher but the class is boring and difficult.

Emily is knowledgeable about what she is teaching, and is very approachable. She does not make students feel uncomfortable when asking  questions. She will make you think for your self for a solution. As mentioned AU16 was her first semester at OSU, and it's evident.  GIS is not easy and don't expect a cake walk.

This is Emily's first semester here at Ohio State - so I can cut her some slack - but not so much that her teaching methods don't warrant some sort of complaint. To describe her exams as meticulous is an understatement - they're extremely hard. She tends to get sidetracked during lecture, resulting in half of the students not paying attention.

Stringer is a great guy and a good professor. He grades easy. Do the work and you will pass his class. He has seen it all so listen when he talks and ask questions. He draws really cool pictures of planes. Loved having him.

Class is easy but unfortunately I am unable to sit through a 3 hour lecture that's not interesting to me. If I did go, I left half way through during breaks. However you can still get an A by not going, attendance isn't mandatory. As long as
you show up to the crash labs and do the homework, you're good. Professor takes long to respond to emails

He has a ton of industry knowledge and very cool stories, and cares a lot about his students. The class is super fun and engaging and I learned a lot from it. We were able to do an actual crash lab at the OSU airport, which was very cool.

Dr. Pruchnicki is undoubtedly the best professor for anything human factor related. He has a background as both a pilot, FAA investigator, and does research in the ISE department. The class itself is relatively easy, weekly quiz (lowest grade one is dropped), 2 midterms, and 1 non-cumulative final. The reading can be long but the slides are enough.

Shawn was the most experienced and knowledgeable professor I have had and he cares about the students. He is extremely passionate about aviation and human factors. The class is mostly lectures and readings, but Shawn offers stories about personal experiences that tie into the lectures making class very interesting.

This class ended up meeting for three hours once a week (which wasn't his fault), but made it harder to pay attention. However, he has a lot of stories/experiences that he shares and he really cares about his students. The lectures are powerpoint heavy and there are a lot of readings, but it's an important class and if you study you'll do well.

Shawn is the most knowledgeable and experienced professor I have had. However, his lectures consist of "Death by Powerpoint" presentations (easily 80+ slides). The quizzes are only 5 questions, making it very hard to know what to study for. This course could very easily be asynchronous, and really just made way more difficult than it needs to be.

Most inspirational professor I have ever had. His experience is unmatched and Shawn does an incredible job of tying personal stories to course material. This makes it very easy to a) pay attention and b) get a better understanding of the lecture content. Shawn is very easygoing and cares about his students.

Nice guy. Lots of experience in the human factors side of aviation. Grade is based on 2 midterms. 1 final, 1 group paper, attendance, and 7 out of 9 quizzes over lectures. Tests are highly based on quizzes and some content in the textbook. Questions on quizzes are pretty much from the lecture slides. Very educational class.
One of the best classes I took at OSU. Not too challenging, and very interesting all the way. Shawn is great.

Shawn is a great professor. Keeps lectures interesting and fun. Has lots of industry experience. Grading is pretty easy. Attendance is taken every day via sign-in sheet. Overall, great ISE 3700 professor.

Dr. Pruchnicki is an industry leader in accident investigation and uses lots of interesting examples from airplane accidents over the last 100 years. For the class, there is usually a typed assignment about once a week, and you may get a few points off, but you will get an A on most assignments if you show good understanding and most finish w/ an A

Shawn brings industry experience and a love of his career and teaching to the classroom. He is extremely interested in the material and is extremely helpful to his students. One of my best professors ever.

I had professor Dickman for Aviation 2200. This class is a more literature heavy aviation class. Professor Dickman is a really easy grader, and you will do good as long as you put some sort of effort into the class. I would recommend not waiting till the last second to do your work, however.
I took AVN2300 with Professor Dickman, she knows her stuff and cares about her students. She is very approachable, and recommend taking any course with her.
Very chill and good teacher. Actually cares if you understand

Melanie is a great person, not so great professor. I put in little to no effort to receive an A in her class. Her modules were very unorganized and I struggled finding important information often. She is happy to help when given the chance, but teaching is not her calling. I was hoping to learn more from this class than I did.
The class is very simple with only a few assignments throughout the year. Only one exam and a couple of papers but Brian truly cares more about his students and their learning than some grade.
This was a study abroad class and was so much fun. He is a really great guy, cares about his students, and wants everyone to succeed.

Really laid back. First part of the course is about basic governmental functions. The other part is guest speakers. You do a big paper the whole semester and submit it as a final. One group project. There is an exam that covers the first couple of weeks. This class isnt that bad.

Really easy going and nice guy. He deliberately makes the class something you shouldn't stress about. Only 1 midterm and a paper. The rest of the class are pop quizzes about a public policy book/online readings (but those grades can be substituted by reflection papers). REALLY easy grader.

Greg is the man. Had him for 2000 and 3000 and he's the best. Has a lot of experience and won't waste your time. Will get you in and out and focus on the important stuff, no tiny insignificant info. Also some great guest speakers. Literally just attend and you'll have to try very hard not to get an A while also feeling like u learned something.

Greg Kociba is a great professor with lots of experience in the aviation industry. He does require you to read the textbook for weekly quiz, but it is not necessary. Lecture slides are concise and straight to the point. He does have guest speakers and asks about them on the exams. Exams are fair. Definitely would take Greg's class again.

Greg has a lot of knowledge and experience. Go to class and talk to him. Meet with him one on one and ask about his experience. He is a great guy to know and a great professor. Loved his class! He has so much to share, you just have to ask and be present in class. My favorite professor at OSU!

This was Greg's first time teaching this course and did a great job making a historically boring class very interesting. He took the material and related it to his previous industry experience which would help make the information stick. Overall, I had low expectations for the class but he made it so I showed up every day and looked forward to it
Completely disorganized class with little structure. Changed the way he graded assignments multiple different times. Terrible Professor and a terrible way to close off my final semester.
You'd have to try to not get an A in the class. Super easygoing, makes the lectures fun, and cares about his students.
Oddly specific online quizzes

Really enjoyed this course with him, he works with students directly and really cares about students understanding the material. Definitely don't skip lecture, participation and attendance are heavy grades and some exam questions are based off lecture conversations rather than just notes. 10/10 loved having him as a professor!

The teacher is really nice and funny, but the class is a complete joke. Easiest A ever, however, you won't really learn much everything is repetitive, not marketing background. Slides are confusing, I was expecting to actually learn something about Airlines marketing. Take this class if you don't care about learning LOL

half the exam questions are ridiculous, studied but also have to know even specific number of questions like (how much would this cost) questions are not an accurate representation of what you learned in class
Adam the best teacher I've ever had essawy

Professor Beckman is a great instructor in that he truly wants his students to succeed. He is lenient with grading as long as you follow his clear instructions and rubric. He offers a ton of extra credit and make up opportunities. Highly recommend if you are looking for a stress-free class environment!

Does not use any sort of powerpoints or visual aids so it's really important to take notes. Fun class, good discussions. Outside of a few quizzes, a book with some quizzes, and a few papers, it's a chill class.

Great guy. Lectures were easy to sit through, tests were fine. Genuinely cares about his students. The books we had to read were not very relevant, but he tried to make them interesting and engage people.

you have to read a book throughout the semester and take a quiz on it each week of a chapter or two. you have a lecture on mondays(not tested on), group project wednesdays(you only present every other week), quiz and discussion friday. hes really cool and knows a lot about the industry. if you miss a quiz its really easy to make up.

I LOVED Yannis!!! He is so nice, funny, and most importantly understanding. FAA requires attendance of all classes, so you have to pay for every class missed which is annoying, but out of his control. Besides that there are very little homeworks (2-3) and like 3 exams which is all you're graded on so just pay attention and study.

Professor Barbas, affectionately known as Yannis, is a very kind hearted man. He truly cares about his students, and will always be prepared to help. He's as flexible as he can be, even moving exams at the request of the class. Unfortunately, the FAA makes things hard, so attendance is mandatory every day. You can always ask questions and for help.

I loved having him as a professor and he really cares about his students. For this class, if you dont already know much about aviation, it can be difficult. The only assignments really are the exams. I enjoyed the class and the content though.

Yannis is an amazing person who truly cares about what he teaches. The grade you get is directly correlated to how much effort and studying you put in. There are tons of topics covered in depth in a short time period. The class is very rigid due to the Part 141 setting.

Yannis is a truly awesome professor/ instructor. I took his advanced Multi-Engine Land course my junior year at OSU. He breaks down extremely complex topics into terms anyone can understand. He takes his time and ensures everyone fully understand the material. He loves participation, and frankly its through the participation you learn the most.

Very interesting class, but requires lots of studying in preparation for exams or quizzes. Only 6 graded assignments for the entire semester, so make sure you are on top of the material. Free textbooks, and attendance is required for attaining a flight spot. Wish there were more opportunities to raise my grade. Barbas is one of the best profs ever.
If you want to fly a plane, you have to be at all the classes and he gets very upset no matter your excuse. I get that, but we have lives to deal with too.
Exams based on lectures. Go to class, take good notes, and if you're having difficulty with a subject, reach out to him and/or use the FAA materials he references.

Yanni was one of my favorite professors Ive had. Theres a lot of material to get through, so the class is fast paced, but if you put in the effort outside of class its not too difficult. Attendance is mandatory (per FAA regulations). Lots of stories and examples from his years in the airlines keep it interesting and relevant.

Professor Barbas, Yannis as he prefers to be called provided great examples and shared relatable stories with the class while ensuring the class was an inclusive and fun experience. He spent time after class to answer questions and give feedback. Although there is a ton of information, he ensured we all felt visible by engaging us when needed.

In my 11 years of aviation and years at OSU, Barbas is the best professor I have had at the university. He is incredibly knowledgeable and his career shows it. No textbook needed but outside materials are. FAA driven class and he teaches to standard. If you do not put in the time you will do poorly. In aviation you must know your stuff.

Yannis (Barbas) is an engaging lecturer who kept the material interesting and fun. Everything is on slides, 2 midterms and a final, 2-3 easy homeworks, must show up to every lecture by FAA regulations. I'm not in the school of aviation yet I thought the class was brilliant and am definitely going for a private pilot's license now.

I really enjoyed this course and look forward to taking future courses with Yannis. This is simply the type of class where you will get a good grade if you put in the work, but if you slack, your grade will reflect that. Yannis is incredibly knowledgeable and really makes the course fun. He was also very caring and always willing to help students!
Mr. Barbas is very knowledgable. The class can be difficult at times but he is very accessible outside of class and is ready to help.

Mr. Barbas (Yannis) is a great instructor. Hes extremely fair, but if you dont put in the work, you simply wont do well. He instructs this class well, but he is also a great resource for career advice. Come ready to learn, and youll do just fine.

I found the grading to be totally fair and even had some extra credit opportunities. Just pay attention and if you zone out just take some basic notes on the power points and you should be fine. I think he has a lot of experience with the material and explains it in a simple and entertaining way. Very understanding and gives good feedback.

For all complaining remember that this is a AVIATION class that directly translates to you going up in an airplane (a lot of folk for the first time) and being in charge for the lives of those on the ground and onboard. If you can't handle it go pursue something else, otherwise try and learn something from a guy who's got 36 years under his belt.

Took this class hearing amazing things about this professor, only to find out he's a very unfair grader. He requires maximum detail on exams and has very unclear grading criteria. My grade suffered because of this. When I brought this to his attention he said that's life in the real world. Never want this professor again.

Hes a great guy and truly cares for his students. Hes good at explaining things over time but sometimes gets ahead of himself. Just keep asking questions and he will help you. Fair amount of studying required. Dont take this class if you dont plan on becoming a pilot. Its regulated by the FAA.

Not sure why some people have negative ratings on him. Probably one of the easiest classes I have ever taken at OSU. All you have is a few Quizzes and like 2 tests, no homework. Only thing that sucks is that attendance is mandatory due to FAA requirements.

Just an all around great guy. You can tell he really wants you to succeed and it shows in his passion. He answered any question I had almost instantly and if you pay attention the class is very straight forward and easy to manage. One of the best professors I had.
Amazing guy and knows a lot about aviation! Classes are interesting with quizzes and tests being fairly simple. Definitely one of the best classes and people I have met so far!

Yannis is a great professor. He is an easy grader as long you try, he actively tries to give extra credit. He is hilly experienced and genuinely cares how you do. Its an easy class where attendance is mandatory by the FAA. I have to believe that all of the negative comments are coming from people who are not trying or working with him to help you
hes very fast , and he makes everything so stressful.

I really liked Yannis. The lectures were long but his humor kept your attention. I don't know why people say this class was so hard. I passed with a high A and didn't do a whole lot of studying. Just pay attention because he only covers topics once and it's your responsibility to stay up on past material.

He picks the hardest possible questions for tests and no matter how hard u study u will never get 100. He looks for points to take off and is not lenient at all. He's a very nice and helpful guy but when it comes to passing his class he makes it as hard as he can.

Yannis is extremely experienced and he has rewritten all of the old powerpoints for private pilot ground. Apparently they used to be terrible, I am sad to read all these negative reviews because he is so good at explaining and teaching his job outside the university is managing training for NetJets. He grades as if you know the point you get points

Yannis is a smart guy, but a bad professor. He can't teach, plain and simple. You get lost in his lectures, and he does a lot of pointless proofs. The tests are very hard, you think you know your stuff and then he throws a curve ball on the exams.

I don't think he is the right one to teach this class, heavy material, his slides make no sense and on top of that he doesn't respect his students. Don't take him you will truly regret it!. Even if he is the only person that teaches it I would rather you go take it somewhere else than take it with him.

The worst professor I have had in the tow years I've been at the university. His penalties on minor things. He makes stupid jokes and waste time saying crap like garbage in some fake french accent. seriously, he's terrible. don't take him, don't talk to him ignore his existence

You will not pass if you dont come to class because we learn a multitude of things in each lecture. This class is crucial and has few grades so if you dont pay attention and take good notes you wont do well on homework and tests. Professor is great and is passionate about the material. Really great guy.

The class was extremely difficult. He is a nice guy and is very approachable but if you cannot teach yourself then I do not recommend taking him. He likes to go into extreme detail, and a lot of the things taught were only needed if you were going to be PHD in aviation . Be prepared to read the text book, teach yourself, and NEVER miss class!

Tom is awful at teaching. He loves going off on tangents and ends up never getting the point across that he is trying to. He has a hard time articulating whats going through his head. However, he does have a passion for aviation and wants to see you succeed. He just does not know how to teach...

Overall I would say Tom is a good professor. But when it comes to the last two projects he made us do, I didn't enjoy it at all because Tom thinks that we know how to use excel. As long as you get a good group for the project I would say you will be fine.

Tom is a very caring human being, he genuinely has interest in helping the student out. However, he does not always know how to. He definitely knows what he is talking about, he is just not good at passing on the message to students. The class Is a little disorganized, so be aware of that and make sure to understand everything from the first day.

Tom is a very difficult professor to rate. He is probably one of the most experienced individuals in the Aviation Industry. He is EXTREMELY caring, someone you can work with if you have a discrepancy and he lets the students decide the flow of the class. However, he is extremely unclear with his instructions, which can be really confusing sometimes

While I really liked Schaner for 2300 (I'm pretty sure that the "most helpful" review I just saw was my review of him from then), in 4500 and (i'm told) 3000, he is very tough grader on group projects. I'm not sure this professor is capable of giving a 100% on a group assignment.

Schaner is an awesome guy. He is one of the most caring aviation lecturers and wants all of the students to do well. He typically ends class early when he can if he can tell most people are starting to zone out... after all, it is a weather class. He cares more about people understanding contenting and more than willing to work with schedules.
Lectures drag on, but he will end class early if he sees people getting bored. Makes a lot of corny jokes. Loves when people participate. Easy class, good guy. Material is a little outdated.

attendance isnt mandatory but if you go to all 25 classes then right there you get 30/20 on participation which is 20% of your final grade. funny but corny jokes. always gives exam reviews. 10 homework assignments. 3 exams. very knowledgeable and fun guy

Participation, homework, 2 midterms, and a final all worth 20% of final grade. Makes cheesy jokes. Really nice guy. Kinda blows through the slides almost as if he expects you to know the content already, but he posts everything online so it's not that big of a deal.
